titleStmt.title: Letter from Amy Lowell to Richard Aldington, March 5, 1925

physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long. Aldington's address is typed in the heading on the top left of the front page: Richard Aldington, Esq., Malthouse Cottage Padworth Reading, Berks England. On the following pages, “Mr. Aldington – [pg #]” is typed on the right side of the heading.

div.p: I thought I wrote to you long ago, but my secretary assures me that I did not. I am afraid I am a very poor correspondent, but the truth is I have such a lot to do that it is almost impossible for me to get through anything, and I have something like a year's mail waiting for me to answer. It took me so long to do the Keats book that I have not been able to attend to much else. You will have received, or will do so shortly, the book itself – I sent you a copy – and if you will put your eye inside it, you will realize what an awful job it was to do. I hope it will be half as successful in England as it has been here. Here four editions were called for before the book had been out five days, three of the editions preceding publication, and that means ten thousand copies. Jonathan GapeCape, who took sheets over from here for England, bought first five hundred copies and then doubled his order. Of course, we are all hoping that he will have to give still more orders in time, but I do not know, your country is a little prejudiced against most American work, I fear, particularly in this field, where Sir Sidney Colvin is sacrosanct, but I am hoping for the best.

Meanwhile I am coming to England next Summer, really and truly coming, if you can believe it – after eleven years! But I am not coming for pleasure only, I am coming to talk. I am lecturing on Keats, on modern American poetry, and giving readings from my own poems. I am already engaged at various English universities, and rather expect to talk at all of them before I get through. I am speaking twice at Oxford, going up to Edinburgh University in Scotland, talking before the English Association in London, and reading poems round generally to various groups of people in various towns. I
only hope that my health will stand it, because it is going to be a strenuous tour.

One of the things I look forward to especially is seeing you again. I have just got your last book of poems, “The Fool i' the Forest,” but I have not had time to read it yet. In glancing at it, however, I should say that you have departed far from our old Imagist standards.

I am bringing out a new volume of poems next Autumn, but I find that the older one gets, the less time there is for anything in the world. I do not mean for writing poetry, because one takes time for that, but for everything else. I got your book of essays, too, which I read with great interest. But what I want more than anything else is to talk to you, and if you are not always drowned in the country, I trust I may see you with reasonable frequency while I am in England. Mrs. Russell and I arrive on April twenty-first on the “Berengaria” at Southampton, and return in the “Samaria” from Liverpool on July eighteenth. It will be very different from the last time we were there; our whole group seems to have broken up and vanished. There is only Fletcher left. I do not know where Flint is, and that reminds me, I am enclosing a draft for your share of the royalties of the Imagist anthologies, and will you please give Flint's to him. The account is as follows:

3 Imagist Poets at .67-1/2 2.03
10 " " 1916 .67-1/2 6.75
11 " " 1917 .67-1/2 7.43
1/6th of 16.21 is $2.70
This represents both the February 1924 and the August 1924 payments, which I am sending together as they are both so small; my February 1925 statement showed no sales. The two first anthologies went out of print with the August statement, and there are only six copies of the “1917” left, so we shall soon have done with them altogether.

I will not write any more now because the time is short, and I am
very busy getting ready to go abroad, but I hope we shall soon talk. I shall be at the Berkeley Hotel as usual, but perhaps you had better write to me in care of Messrs. Brown, Shipley & Company, 123 Pall Mall, London, S.W., as that will always reach me if I should change quarters.

I forgot to tell you that I saw your friend Mr. Glover, asked him to dinner, and had a very pleasant evening with him. He told me all about you and what you were doing, and if he enjoyed me as much as I enjoyed him he must have had a pleasant time. His wife I had met before; she was staying with some great friends of mine, the William Jameses, giving singing lessons to Mrs. James, she was here last year. I hope they will be in London when I am there.
div.closer: Lots of love, dear Richard, Affectionately yours,

postscript.p: Don't be frightened at the magnitude of the “Keats.” It reads easily, I think.
